author: By Emily Cochrane
title: With Biden Agenda in Limbo, Democrats Work to Sell an Unfinished Promise
description: As President Biden and his allies in Congress work to whittle down the size of their ambitious domestic plans, Democrats must sell a bill without knowing precisely what will be in it.
content: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — When Representative Susan Wild, Democrat of Pennsylvania, accompanied Jill Biden, the first lady, to the Learning Hub, a newly established early education center whose walls were covered with vocabulary words in English and Spanish, on a recent Wednesday morning, Ms. Wild’s constituents were frank about the many unmet needs in their community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Pledges to Pay Family of Those Killed in Botched Kabul Drone Strike
description: The Pentagon offered unspecified amounts to relatives of the 10 civilians who died in Aug. 29 attack and agreed to help relocate those who want to move to the U.S.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon offered unspecified condolence payments this week to the family of the 10 civilians, including seven children, who the military has acknowledged were mistakenly killed on Aug. 29 in the last U.S. drone strike before American troops withdrew from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: U.S.C. to Issue Honorary Degrees to Displaced Japanese Students
description: Jonathan Kaji, former president of the Asian Pacific Alumni Association at the University of Southern California, has been pushing the school to apologize for its treatment of its Nisei students since 2007.
content: In 2007, Jonathan Kaji, then the president of the Asian Pacific Alumni Association at the University of Southern California, inquired about the school’s actions toward its Japanese students in 1942. That was the year President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066, which forcibly removed and detained people of Japanese descent from the West Coast after the bombing of Pearl Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Minnesota’s governor calls up the National Guard to ease crowding in hospitals.
description: Staffing shortages at long-term care facilities are preventing hospitals from discharging patients and admitting new ones.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said on Friday that he would call upon the state’s National Guard to help ease staffing shortages that have kept hospitals from transferring Covid-19 patients for stepped-down care at long-term care facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Carl Zimmer and Sharon LaFraniere
title: An F.D.A. panel explores mixing and matching vaccine doses.
description: The agency’s expert advisers discussed the data on the approach, which is limited.
content: When an advisory panel to federal regulators endorsed boosters for Johnson & Johnson’s one-dose Covid-19 vaccine on Friday, the scientists on the committee discussed a question many people are asking: Is it a good idea to mix and match vaccines?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: In Senator Manchin’s Home State, Universal Pre-K Is Already a Reality
description: A program in West Virginia, partially rolled out while Joe Manchin was governor, could be a model for the nation. But there were challenges, including the 10 years it took to establish.
content: Universal, free preschool is one of the more popular measures in President Biden’s social safety net bill, at least according to polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats Weigh Carbon Tax After Manchin Rejects Key Climate Provision
description: Faced with the likely demise of a central pillar of President Biden’s agenda, the White House and outraged lawmakers are scrambling to find alternatives.
content: WASHINGTON — Some House and Senate Democrats, smarting from a move by Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, to kill a major element of President Biden’s climate plan, are switching to Plan B: a tax on carbon dioxide pollution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Short on Staff, Some Hospices Ask New Patients To Wait
description: “It causes huge distress to tell a family, ‘We can’t serve you,’” said one state hospice organization director.
content: Anne Cotton had enjoyed her years at an assisted living facility in Corvallis, Ore. But at 89, her health problems began to mount: heart failure, weakness from post-polio syndrome, a 30-pound weight loss in a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Pramila Jayapal Won’t Let the Biden Presidency Fail
description: In the infrastructure negotiations, the leader of the House progressive caucus has shown a willingness to play hardball.
content: I RECENTLY confided to Pramila Jayapal, the leader of the House Progressive Caucus, that I was literally losing sleep over the fate of the giant social spending bill she’s negotiating. It’s been impressive to see the left exert control over Congress, refusing to move on legislation cherished by moderates until there’s a deal on a bill containing progressive priorities. At the same time, it’s been terrifying to imagine what it will mean for the Biden presidency — and the future of the country — if an agreement isn’t reached soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: The Cruel Paradox of Linda Evangelista’s Fate
description: A world obsessed with women’s hyper-visibility can dispatch them so swiftly to invisibility.
content: Earlier this month, the former supermodel Linda Evangelista took to Instagram to announce that she was suing the company behind the cosmetic procedure known as CoolSculpting for tens of millions of dollars because, she said, she had been “brutally disfigured.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Macron Commemorates 1961 Paris Police Killing of Algerian Protesters
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France is the country’s first head of state to attend an event marking the deaths, which officials ignored for decades.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron on Saturday became the first French head of state to attend commemorations of the mass killing of Algerian independence protesters by the Paris police 60 years ago, a brutal episode that many historians consider the most violent repression of a peaceful demonstration in contemporary Western Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: NASA’s Lucy Launches on 12-Year Mission to Jupiter’s Trojan Asteroids
description: The elaborate journey of the robotic spacecraft will offer close encounters with some of the solar system’s least understood objects.
content: NASA embarked on a 12-year mission to study a group of asteroids on Saturday with the launch of Lucy, a robotic explorer that will meander through the unexplored caverns of deep space to find new clues about the creation of our solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Carl Zimmer
title: F.D.A. Panel Unanimously Recommends Johnson & Johnson Booster Shots
description: But many panel members said J. & J. recipients might also benefit from the option of a Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna booster, an action that an F.D.A. official said was possible.
content: WASHINGTON — A key federal advisory committee voted unanimously Friday to recommend Johnson & Johnson booster shots, most likely clearing the way for all 15 million people who got the company’s one-dose coronavirus vaccine to receive a second shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What’s Going on With Halloween This Year?
description: It depends on where you live. If it’s in an apartment building, you might have to wait another year to go trick-or-treating.
content: Q: My children have been asking me for weeks: Will trick-or-treating happen this Halloween? Our Upper West Side co-op has been silent so far, but what’s the word on the street? Are buildings planning to allow children to take the elevator from floor to floor to get their loot? Personally, I have mixed feelings about all this. I want my children to enjoy something normal, but I also worry about the potential for an outbreak in the building. So how are buildings approaching this sticky subject?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: Robert Durst has Covid, his lawyer says, and is on a ventilator.
description: The 78-year-old millionaire and former real estate mogul was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday for the murder of a friend in 2000.
content: The millionaire and former real estate mogul Robert A. Durst, 78, is on a ventilator in a Los Angeles hospital after testing positive for Covid-19, days after being sentenced to life in prison for the 2000 murder of his confidante.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Paula Badosa, Victoria Azarenka in Surprise Indian Wells Final
description: Many tennis stars have shut down their seasons or pleaded fatigue after a long year, but Azarenka and Badosa have thrived in the California desert.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Victoria Azarenka’s and Paula Badosa’s tennis seasons did not begin on a high note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: What Are Political ‘Surgeries’ in Britain?
description: The person-to-person meetings with voters give Britons unusually good access to their political representatives. But questions are being asked about whether the tradition can continue.
content: David Amess, a British lawmaker who was stabbed to death on Friday, warned in a book published less than a year ago that attacks on members of Parliament had spoiled “the great British tradition” of voters meeting politicians, adding that a deadly assault “could happen to any of us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Case for File Cabinets
description: I would have never uploaded my fourth-grade report on caribou into the cloud. But I still liked pulling it out of the drawer labeled A-F.
content: Remember filing cabinets? Those lumbering, clattering towers of drawers stuffed full of Pendaflex folders? They were once vital to every workplace, as much a part of the landscape as desks and chairs. There was always a warren of them in a back room somewhere, and no matter what your eventual profession, if you ever served time as an intern, an executive assistant, a clerk or a catalog manager, you filed. You filed and filed until your thumbs wore down. You’d painstakingly recenter those metal rods, always prone to slipping free; you’d occasionally handwrite a label onto the perforated fragment of paper nested inside each plastic tab, folding it just so and inserting it, only to see it worm out the other end. And only after you’d climbed a few rungs on the corporate ladder could you let all this filing go to someone else, another rung down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Money Floods the Race for Control of Congress, More Than a Year Early
description: The main House war chests for both Democrats and Republicans have a combined $128 million in the bank — more than double the sum at this point in 2020.
content: A dizzying amount of money is already pouring into the battles for the House and the Senate more than a year before the 2022 elections, as Republicans are bullish on their chances to take over both chambers in the first midterm election under President Biden, given the narrow margins keeping Democrats in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Can a Carbon-Emitting Iron Ore Tycoon Save the Planet?
description: Andrew Forrest made a mining fortune. Now he wants to lead a climate change revolution — and beat the fossil fuel giants along the way.
content: CLOUDBREAK, Australia — Standing at the foot of a diesel truck as large as a dinosaur, Andrew Forrest juggled the microphone and then delivered the message that he knew the miners might see as a threat to their jobs and identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand Attempts a Record-Setting ‘Vaxathon’
description: The country took a different approach to encouraging vaccinations on Saturday, with barbecues, a telethon and the chance to get jabbed in the business-class seat of a Boeing 787.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Since New Zealand closed its borders in March 2020, setting the stage for one of the world’s most successful Covid-19 responses, the wide-body jets that once ferried its citizens to every corner of the globe have mostly been redeployed for shipping freight. And the vast majority of Kiwis have, throughout the pandemic, been as flightless as their eponymous birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: The Yukon Territory imposes a vaccine mandate as cases surge in northern Canada.
description: Health care workers and others in the Yukon must be fully vaccinated by Nov. 30. The territory is also starting a vaccination passport program.
content: Coronavirus vaccinations will soon be mandatory for public service and health care workers in the Yukon Territory, government authorities there announced on Friday, as the territory’s next-door neighbors grappled with a spike in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
title: With Lawmaker’s Killing, U.K. Confronts a New Episode of Terrorism
description: The police conducted searches and questioned the suspect as Prime Minister Boris Johnson and other leaders paid respects to David Amess, who was fatally stabbed while meeting with constituents.
content: LONDON — As Prime Minister Boris Johnson and other British leaders paid their respects on Saturday to a Conservative lawmaker fatally stabbed a day earlier, the police were searching three addresses in the London area while continuing to question the 25-year-old man arrested after the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Mining for Gold in Australia’s Migrant Past
description: “New Gold Mountain” highlights the complications of belonging for immigrants then and now.
content: On the dusty Ballarat goldfields, a group of Chinese miners find the body of a white woman dressed in Chinese clothing. Knowing what deadly consequences might result if the authorities think a Chinese person murdered a white woman, they hide the body. So begins “New Gold Mountain,” a new historical drama on SBS that has quickly become popular for its fresh take on a familiar element of Australia’s past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Glenn Youngkin Talks About Virginia. His Base Talks About Donald Trump.
description: Republicans in Virginia are saying what their nominee for governor will not: The governor’s race is a proxy for Mr. Trump’s grievances.
content: GLEN ALLEN, Va. — The event was billed as a rally for Virginia conservatives ahead of next month’s election for governor. But it was mostly about Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: How 3 Strangers a World Away Came to the Rescue of a Badly Burned Afghan Girl
description: The story of 8-year-old Asma, injured by a U.S. tear-gas canister, echoes the heartbreak and heroism of the 20-year American misadventure in Afghanistan.
content: Nabila had been fasting in the hope that God would get her family through the gates of Hamid Karzai International Airport. So when a tear-gas canister thrown by American forces trying to disperse the crowd hit her 8-year-old daughter, Asma, she was too weak to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: 8 Wedding Gifts That Do Some Good, Too
description: Experts share socially conscious ideas for couples who prefer things that do more than just surprise and delight.
content: Even if they’ve requested no gifts, showing up to a wedding without something for the couple can feel awkward. Newlyweds may direct guests to donate to a favorite cause or charity on their behalf, but when they don’t, it can be hard to find an alternative to arriving empty-handed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Venezuela, a Rum Maker Offers Gangsters a Life Outside of Crime
description: In the process, the family running the company, Ron Santa Teresa, has gone from bankruptcy to exporting an award-winning vintage rum.
content: SABANETA, Venezuela — They once used the house to hide their kidnapping victims as they awaited ransom. Now they are converting it into an office for a rum distribution business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Defining Test for Mr. Biden
description: The president needs to make the case for a big expansion of government spending.
content: When the federal government started sending monthly checks to families with children earlier this year, Democrats predicted that the program would be a big hit. They were counting on public support to extend the payments beyond this year, and to pass a broader expansion of federal aid for families.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Hit Toys for Japanese Adults: The More Mundane the Better
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 16, 2021.
content: “‘This is ridiculous’ is the highest form of praise.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Those Buried at Guantánamo Graveyard Never Found Their Way Home
description: The U.S. military cemetery at Guantánamo Bay offers a history of the century-old base — minus the outpost’s war-on-terror mission.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — At first glance, the graveyard down a road behind a locked gate on this remote U.S. Navy base looks like a miniature version of Arlington National Cemetery. But these marble headstones tell an entirely different story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Isabelle Niu
title: China’s Latest Craze: Scripted Murders, With Real Tears and Piracy
description: “Scripted homicide” clubs have opened around the country as young people look for ways to escape and connect. Naturally, the government has questions.
content: The murders are scripted. The money is real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Houston’s Shortstop Was Right on Time With Go-Ahead Homer
description: Carlos Correa’s mammoth home run, and over-the-top celebration, gave the Astros a strong start to a battle of pitching-starved teams.
content: HOUSTON — There are bat flips and home runs celebrations. And then there is what Houston Astros star shortstop Carlos Correa did on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Airlines in Japan and South Korea get creative to revive pandemic-dampened demand.
description: How about inexpensive passes good for a month of domestic flights? Or popular in-flight meals to on-the-ground customers?
content: Border restrictions that are part of the pandemic response in Japan have deterred most tourists from visiting the country. So one airline is taking an unusual approach to generate revenue by offering extreme discounts on domestic flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: They Resisted Getting Vaccinated. Here’s Why They Changed Their Minds.
description: Mandates have prompted a surge in vaccinations among those who had held out. Some report feeling relief; others, anguish and resentment.
content: In the Bronx, a youth counselor closed his eyes and steeled himself for the shot. In Queens, a nurse calmed herself by humming gospel music. In Manhattan, a graduate student asked one last question about fertility while reviewing the consent form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Regional Dog Variety
description: Erik Agard and Caitlin Reid make a snack of a Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s been far too long since we’ve solved a Times puzzle from either of these constructors, Caitlin Reid and Erik Agard, a couple of puzzle-making hot dogs who collaborated on another terrific themeless grid over a year ago and have been occupied mostly elsewhere in 2021. Welcome back!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: More Lead-Tainted Water in Michigan Draws Attention to Nation’s Aging Pipes
description: The crises in Benton Harbor and Flint expose broader failures as a congressional push to address the country’s troubled water system stalls.
content: BENTON HARBOR, Mich. — During the three years that officials have known about dangerous amounts of lead flowing from faucets in Benton Harbor, Mich., they have sent out notices, distributed filters and tried to improve water treatment. But the problems persisted, and some residents said they never heard about the risks of the toxic water coming from their taps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: U.S. Extradites Key Financial Ally of Venezuela’s President, Inciting Retaliation
description: Alex Saab, a Colombian businessman, is accused in the U.S. of siphoning millions from programs intended to help the needy in Venezuela.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The United States extradited a top ally of Venezuela’s authoritarian government on Saturday, his lawyer said, prompting a swift retaliation from Venezuelan officials that immediately threatened a fledgling effort to resolve the country’s political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Sky Bring Hoops Championship Buzz Back to Chicago
description: Sky forward Kahleah Copper’s hot shooting against the Mercury in Game 3 of the W.N.B.A. finals has the team one win away from its first title.
content: CHICAGO — It has been more than 23 years since Michael Jordan stole the ball from Utah Jazz forward Karl Malone, drove the length of the court and nailed a jumper to give his Chicago Bulls a 1-point win in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals. The unforgettable sequence secured the Bulls’ sixth championship and had Chicago fans reveling in a shared moment of pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
title: Beirut, a City Where Everyone Gets By, Revisits Sectarian Violence
description: Lebanon’s capital thrives on its religious diversity, but sectarian tensions and memories of civil war lurk just beneath the surface.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tony Nohra, a shopkeeper in a Christian neighborhood of Beirut, was receiving a shipment of yogurt on Friday, the day after sectarian clashes killed seven people in the city,  and talking about how many Shiite Muslim friends he had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: To Learn Bees’ Secrets, Count Them One by One
description: The decline of bee populations is a looming crisis, but there is a dearth of scientific data. Hyperlocal researchers, with nets and notebooks, could be key.
content: All through late summer and early fall, Max McCarthy, a graduate student at Rutgers University, walked around wetlands in northern New Jersey with a mesh net catching bees, which he marked with tiny colored pens. Three dots, each a different color, on the bees’ minuscule thoraxes before releasing them again. He wrote this information in his notebooks, counting up the insects one by one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danté Stewart
title: How I Learned That Jesus Is Black
description: For too long, I associated whiteness with holiness.
content: For years, I made my home with white people in white churches. I knew how to run and to hide and to move my body in ways that made white people feel more safe and less racist and more godly and less violent. Whether on the football field or in the pulpit, my performance gave them what they never deserved: confidence that the world was OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: What’s next for the business of longevity?
description: DealBook spoke with the Harvard researcher and biotech founder David Sinclair about the opportunities and challenges of hacking the human lifespan.
content: Investors including Larry Ellison, Jeff Bezos and Peter Thiel have spent billions on the business of living longer. The appeal is clear: more time to spend with loved ones, achieve goals and enjoy new experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Azi Paybarah
title: Deputies Shot in Fatal Attack in Houston Were Close Friends
description: One deputy who was shot in the back was in stable condition, but the long-term impact of his wounds remained unclear.
content: One Texas deputy was killed and two others were injured in an early-morning shooting outside a Houston bar, law enforcement officials said at a news conference on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
title: Instagram Struggles With Fears of Losing Its ‘Pipeline’: Young Users
description: The app, hailed as Facebook’s growth engine, has privately wrestled with retaining and engaging teenagers, according to internal documents.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Instagram reached one billion users in 2018, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, called it “an amazing success.” The photo-sharing app, which Facebook owns, was widely hailed as a hit with young people and celebrated as a growth engine for the social network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: ‘Fiscal Justice Ratings’ Fight Police Brutality With Finance
description: A new project aims to incorporate the cost of lawsuit settlements and inequality when rating municipal bonds.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: In the Land of the Godfather Comes a Ban on Them
description: Part of the Catholic church in Sicily has imposed a three-year prohibition on naming godparents, arguing that the tradition has become merely a way to fortify family ties — and mob ties, too.
content: CATANIA, Italy — The mother had prepared everything for the baptism. She dressed her infant son Antonio in a handmade satin suit with tails and a matching cream-colored top hat glittering with rhinestones. She hired the photographers and bought the baby a gold cross. She booked a big buffet lunch for the whole clan at the Copacabana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Do I Really Have to Go Trick-or-Treating Again?
description: I enjoyed a break from spooky szn.
content: A confession: One of the few pandemic changes I was happy about in 2020 was avoiding trick-or-treating. We did an outdoor candy hunt in our building’s courtyard, it took 45 minutes instead of three hours, and I got to avoid schlepping around a neighborhood crowded with screaming children. As previously noted, I am a complete washout at making costumes, and because Halloween was a muted affair last year, there was less pressure to make it a Pinterest-perfect spooky szn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Common Core
description: Jeff Chen’s puzzle makes the most of the middle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I have no idea what percentage of crossword solvers pay attention to the names of the constructors. However, I’m sure that percentage has increased in the last couple of decades, considering that New York Times puzzles used to appear without bylines until Will Shortz arrived as crossword editor in 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Jelly Roll
description: Eric Berlin sends us on an inward spiral.
content: JELLY ROLL — This tricky variety puzzle, by Eric Berlin, consists of two strands of entries running in the same direction, forming a spiral like a rolled-up poster, and a bonus set of clues that zigzag along those strands in the same direction to form a third set of entries. This means that you use every letter in this puzzle twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: James Bond Has No Time for China
description: America's main rival inspires fear in Hollywood -- and confusion in Americans.
content: The final James Bond outing for Daniel Craig, “No Time to Die,” also marks a notable milestone for Bondian geopolitics: The franchise just completed a five-movie arc with a single lead actor, and amid all the globe-trotting and intrigue you would barely know that China existed. Shanghai and Macau were brief backdrops, and one villain had been tortured, offstage and in the past, by Chinese security forces — but overall a series released across the years of China’s rise gave little hint that America’s leading rival mattered any more than any other exotic Bondian locale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Whether Free, Affordable or Pricey, Testing Requirements Can Include a Headache
description: Coronavirus testing prices vary widely and can reach into the hundreds of dollars, making it hard for some travelers to budget for the added expense.
content: For those who have been traveling internationally during the pandemic, getting a coronavirus test has become an integral part of the process. Many countries, including the United States, require a negative test result for entry, which has forced travel agents, hoteliers and others to establish testing and authentication procedures and, in many cases, to work together to ease the process for travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Did You See That Video of the Subway Rat Hauling the Crab?
description: SubwayCreatures, a popular Instagram account, offers a voyeuristic look at New York’s bizarre and wacky underground.
content: When Hurricane Ida struck New York last month, an incredible, terrifying scene occurred in the subway station at 28th and Seventh Avenue in Midtown Manhattan. Water began gushing from under the platform in a violent, torrid geyser, turning the subway into a Universal ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: After Iraqi Election, a Shiite Leader Emerges as an Unlikely U.S. Ally
description: The U.S. once threatened to kill Muqtada al-Sadr as his militia battled occupying forces. Now, the powerful cleric is helping Washington by keeping Iran at bay.
content: BAGHDAD — Standing at a podium with an Iraqi flag by his side, the cleric Muqtada al-Sadr looked the part of a statesman as he read a postelection address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry, Alan Feuer and Matthew Rosenberg
title: 90 Seconds of Rage
description: Inside, the violence was winding down. But outside, seven men found themselves at the center of breathtaking brutality.
content: Inside, the violence was winding down. But outside, seven men found themselves at the center of breathtaking brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Best to Save the Planet
description: Readers debate whether solar geoengineering, advocated in a guest essay, is a good way to address global warming.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
